titleStmt.title: The new Scotch-jigg: or, The bonny cravat Johnny wooed Jenny to tye his cravat; but Jenny perceiving what he would be at, with delayes put him off, till she found out his mind; and then afterwards she proved more kind: at length both parties were well agreed, and went to the kirck to be wed with all speed. Tune of, Jenny come tye my, &c.

editionStmt.edition: This text is an enriched version of the TCP digital transcription A52977 of text R220447 in the English Short Title Catalog (Wing N752). Textual changes and metadata enrichments aim at making the text more computationally tractable, easier to read, and suitable for network-based collaborative curation by amateur and professional end users from many walks of life. The text has been tokenized and linguistically annotated with MorphAdorner. The annotation includes standard spellings that support the display of a text in a standardized format that preserves archaic forms ('loveth', 'seekest'). Textual changes aim at restoring the text the author or stationer meant to publish.

respStmt.resp: This text has not been fully proofread

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 6 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 1 1-bit group-IV TIFF page image.

publicationStmt.pubPlace: Evanston,IL, Notre Dame, IN, St. Louis, MO

The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The new Scotch-jigg: or, The bonny cravat Johnny wooed Jenny to tye his cravat; but Jenny perceiving what he would be at, with delayes put him off, till she found out his mind; and then afterwards she proved more kind: at length both parties were well agreed, and went to the kirck to be wed with all speed. Tune of, Jenny come tye my, &c.

publicationStmt.publisher: printed for W. Thackeray, T. Passenger, and W. Whiwood,

notesStmt.note: Verse - "As Johnny met Jenny a going to play,".
Reproduction of the original in the Bodleian Library.
